question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Lane control signals are placed over lanes to indicate which ones are open for driving.

text.default: This sign means:
text.mandarin: 这个标志的意思是：

answer.default: school crosswalk, yield to pedestrians; if there is a crossing guard follow directions
answer.mandarin: 学校人行横道，请礼让行人；如果有交通指挥员，请按照指示行驶。

distractor_1.default: pedestrian crosswalk

distractor_2.default: school zone - reduce speed

distractor_3.default: playground area

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: School, playground and crosswalk signs tell you the rules to follow in areas where you need to be extra cautious.

text.default: If you get angry or upset before driving, you should
text.mandarin: 如果你在驾驶前感到愤怒或不安，你应该

answer.default: calm down before you drive
answer.mandarin: 在驾驶前冷静下来

distractor_1.default: not think about what made you angry as you drive
distractor_1.mandarin: 在驾驶时不要想着什么让你生气的事情

distractor_2.default: breathe deeply as you drive to regain your self-control
distractor_2.mandarin: 在驾驶时深呼吸，恢复自控力

distractor_3.default: concentrate and be cautious as you drive

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Dangerous Emotions
question.source: Controlling emotions: take a couple of moments to calm yourself down and leave your problems behind before you start to drive.

text.default: A common cause of driver anger and frustration is
text.mandarin: 导致驾驶者愤怒和沮丧的常见原因是

answer.default: being impatient with the driving environment
answer.mandarin: 对驾驶环境不耐烦

distractor_1.default: other people's poor driving

distractor_2.default: an under-powered car

distractor_3.default: poor conditions of the road

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Dangerous Emotions
question.source: Crowded traffic conditions and high-speed freeway driving often cause stress. Being slowed down by other traffic when you're in a hurry produces tension.

text.default: Which of the following is NOT a good way to identify your driving attitude?
text.mandarin: 以下哪种方法不适合确定你的驾驶态度？

answer.default: Blaming all driving errors on others.
answer.mandarin: 将所有驾驶错误归咎于他人。

distractor_1.default: Asking someone you trust to give you some feedback on your driving.
distractor_1.mandarin: 询问你信任的人对你的驾驶提出反馈意见。

distractor_2.default: If you have a close call, asking yourself why it happened.
distractor_2.mandarin: 如果你差点发生事故，问自己为什么会这样。

distractor_3.default: Asking if the poor driving you observe is your own.
distractor_3.mandarin: 询问你所观察到的糟糕驾驶是否是你自己的。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Taking Risks
question.source: Do you find yourself always blaming others for bad driving? If so, then ask yourself: "Is it really their fault or could it be me?"

text.default: Which of the following is MOST likely to make other drivers aggressive?
text.mandarin: 以下哪项最有可能使其他驾驶员变得激进？

answer.default: Not pulling over when a line of traffic has formed behind you.
answer.mandarin: 当车队排成一列排在你后面时不让路。

distractor_1.default: Giving the right of way

distractor_2.default: Taking only one parking spot.

distractor_3.default: Moving over for merging traffic.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Preventing Aggression
question.source: Sharing the road means considering other drivers. What messages do your actions give to other drivers?

text.default: When other drivers honk horns or yell at you,
text.mandarin: 当其他驾驶员按喇叭或对你大喊时，

answer.default: assess the situation and rely on your own knowledge of safe driving practices
answer.mandarin: 评估情况并依靠你自己对安全驾驶规范的知识。

distractor_1.default: you should drive more slowly

distractor_2.default: yell back

distractor_3.default: do what they want you to do

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Preventing Aggression
question.source: If you use your road sense, allow plenty of space and give others the right-of-way, you can help prevent situations that cause aggression.

text.default: If you don't know what other drivers are going to do,
text.mandarin: 如果你不知道其他驾驶员打算做什么，

answer.default: yield the right of way to be safe
answer.mandarin: 礼让行驶以确保安全

distractor_1.default: honk or yell at them

distractor_2.default: take your right of way quickly

distractor_3.default: flash your high beam headlights at them

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Preventing Aggression
question.source: Sharing the road means considering other drivers. What messages do your actions give to other drivers?

text.default: If you feel sleepy while driving you should,
text.mandarin: 如果你在驾驶时感到困倦，你应该，

answer.default: stop somewhere safe, lock your doors, and nap
answer.mandarin: 在安全的地方停车，锁上车门，小睡片刻

distractor_1.default: reduce speed and drive with care

distractor_2.default: turn up the radio and maintain speed
distractor_2.mandarin: 调高收音机音量并保持速度

distractor_3.default: open the window and maintain speed

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Staying Awake
question.source: Being tired is one of the leading causes of crashes. Fatigue affects all stages of the See-Think-Do strategy.

text.default: What factor is involved in over 30% of crash fatalities yearly in British Columbia?
text.mandarin: 每年在不列颠哥伦比亚省有超过30%的交通事故死亡案件中涉及哪个因素？

answer.default: Alcohol.
answer.mandarin: 酒精。

distractor_1.default: Tiredness.

distractor_2.default: Not signalling.

distractor_3.default: Vehicle malfunction.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies
question.source: In an average year in B.C., over 100 people are killed and several thousand injured in police-reported collisions where alcohol was involved.

text.default: If you are going into a curve at high speed, why is taking your foot off the accelerator a good idea before the curve?
text.mandarin: 如果你以高速进入弯道，为什么在弯道之前抬起油门是个好主意？

answer.default: it is a good strategy to help slow you down without using your brakes in the curve.
answer.mandarin: 这是一个很好的策略，在弯道中不使用刹车来帮助你减速。

distractor_1.default: you’ll always need to brake while in the curve
distractor_1.mandarin: 在弯道中总是需要刹车

distractor_2.default: your foot should never be over the accelerator in a curve
distractor_2.mandarin: 你的脚不应该在弯道中踩油门

distractor_3.default: you will need power to accelerate while in the curve.
distractor_3.mandarin: 在弯道中你将需要动力加速。

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control

text.default: Inertia is
text.mandarin: 惯性是

answer.default: the tendency for moving objects to continue moving forward in a straight line
answer.mandarin: 移动物体继续沿直线向前运动的倾向

distractor_1.default: the force that pulls everything towards the earth
distractor_1.mandarin: 将所有事物拉向地球的力量

distractor_2.default: the point around which all of an object's weight is balanced

distractor_3.default: the weight of a vehicle

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: When you go around a curve, inertia tries to keep you going in a straight line. The faster you are going, the greater the force of inertia.

text.default: If you go around a curve too quickly, inertia may cause your vehicle to
text.mandarin: 如果你以过快的速度转弯，惯性可能会导致你的车辆

answer.default: stay in a straight line and go off the road
answer.mandarin: 保持直线并驶离道路

distractor_1.default: go even faster

distractor_2.default: shake uncontrollably

distractor_3.default: lock its brakes

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: When you go around a curve, inertia tries to keep you going in a straight line. The faster you are going, the greater the force of inertia.

text.default: Which of the following is NOT likely to contribute to a vehicle skidding?
text.mandarin: 以下哪项不太可能导致车辆打滑？

answer.default: Driving at a speed suitable to the road conditions
answer.mandarin: 以适合道路条件的速度行驶

distractor_1.default: Going around a corner too fast.

distractor_2.default: Poor driving skills.

distractor_3.default: Sudden change of direction.

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Skid Control
question.source: Skids happen when drivers slam on the brakes and steer at the same time, go around a corner too fast or accelerate suddenly.

text.default: Anti-lock braking systems (ABS) are different from regular brakes. Emergency braking with ABS involves
text.mandarin: 防抱死制动系统（ABS）与普通制动系统不同。 使用ABS进行紧急制动涉及

answer.default: squeezing the brakes and holding them on, until you come to a complete stop
answer.mandarin: 挤压刹车并保持刹车，直到完全停下来

distractor_1.default: constantly pumping the brakes hard to stop
distractor_1.mandarin: 持续强力地泵动刹车以停车

distractor_2.default: never fully stopping

distractor_3.default: switching between pumping the brakes hard, then gently
distractor_3.mandarin: 在强力泵动刹车和轻轻泵动之间切换

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Emergency Braking
question.source: In an emergency situation, drivers using ABS should apply continuous, firm, hard pressure to the brake pedal until the vehicle stops.

text.default: If a vehicle has a standard transmission, coasting down a hill with the clutch pushed "IN"
text.mandarin: 如果一辆车是手动挡，在坡道上离合器踩“进”时滑行

answer.default: is unsafe and illegal
answer.mandarin: 是不安全和违法的

distractor_1.default: is a good alternative to using the brakes
distractor_1.mandarin: 是使用刹车的一个好的替代方案

distractor_2.default: is all right in good weather
distractor_2.mandarin: 在良好的天气条件下是可以的

distractor_3.default: gives you more vehicle control

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: It is illegal to coast downhill in neutral or with the clutch in. You need to be in gear to safely control your vehicle.

text.default: The beginning of a rainfall may cause roads to be particularly slippery because
text.mandarin: 降雨开始时可能导致道路特别滑的原因是因为

answer.default: the water mixes with oil on the road
answer.mandarin: 水与路面上的油混合

distractor_1.default: your tires become cold

distractor_2.default: the water cools the road down quickly
distractor_2.mandarin: 水迅速降低了路面温度

distractor_3.default: the water washes the road clean quickly

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Loss of Traction
question.source: Rain makes the road surface slippery, especially during the beginning of a rainfall. The rain mixes with the oil on the road to create a slippery, oily film.

text.default: Hydroplaning occurs
text.mandarin: 发生水上滑行时

answer.default: when your tires float on a film of water and lose traction with the road
answer.mandarin: 当你的车轮漂浮在一层水膜上，并且与路面失去了牵引力

distractor_1.default: when the road is very uneven

distractor_2.default: only when you are travelling in deep water and the car is lifted
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有当你在深水中行驶并且车子被抬起时

distractor_3.default: only when it is raining heavily

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Loss of Traction
question.source: In a hydroplaning situation the driver instantly loses control of steering and braking. It can happen in rain or standing water.

text.default: Which of these is NOT a good strategy for night driving?
text.mandarin: 以下哪项不是夜间驾驶的好策略？

answer.default: Staying closer to the car ahead so you can see their tail lights more clearly.
answer.mandarin: 保持与前方车辆更近，以便更清楚地看到它们的尾灯。

distractor_1.default: Adjusting your mirror for night driving.
distractor_1.mandarin: 调整后视镜以适应夜间驾驶。

distractor_2.default: Keeping the interior lights off except for the instrument panel.
distractor_2.mandarin: 除了仪表板之外，将内部灯光关闭。

distractor_3.default: Increasing your following distance.

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Overdriving the Headlights
question.source: Strategies for night driving also include glancing to the right edge of the road to avoid glare from oncoming lights.

text.default: When driving in bad weather, you should make your vehicle easier for others to see by
text.mandarin: 在恶劣天气驾驶时，你应该通过以下方式让其他人更容易看到你的车辆

answer.default: turning on the low beam headlights
answer.mandarin: 打开近光灯

distractor_1.default: turning on the parking lights

distractor_2.default: turning on emergency flashers

distractor_3.default: flashing high beam headlights

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Using the Headlights; Loss of Visibility
question.source: In bad weather, you may have to pull over and stop if necessary until the visibility improves.

text.default: If your vehicle breaks down on a busy highway you should NOT
text.mandarin: 如果你的车辆在繁忙的高速公路上抛锚，你不应该

answer.default: try to do roadside repairs on your vehicle
answer.mandarin: 试图在路边修理你的车辆

distractor_1.default: stay with your vehicle and raise the hood
distractor_1.mandarin: 留在车辆旁边，把引擎盖打开

distractor_2.default: set out flares or warning triangles
distractor_2.mandarin: 设置路边标志或警示三角牌

distractor_3.default: turn on hazard lights

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Engine Problems
question.source: If your engine ever fails, signal and steer to the edge of the road, turn on your hazard lights, stay with your vehicle, put an S.O.S. notice in your windshield.

text.default: Letting up on the brake just before hitting a large animal that you can't avoid
text.mandarin: 在无法避免的情况下，即将撞到一只大动物时放松刹车

answer.default: lessens the chance of it going through the windshield
answer.mandarin: 减少了它冲破挡风玻璃的机会

distractor_1.default: minimizes the damage to your car
distractor_1.mandarin: 最大限度地减少了对你车辆的损坏

distractor_2.default: damages the animal less

distractor_3.default: stops the car from skidding

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Animals on the Road
question.source: If the animal is large and you can't stop in time, brake firmly and steer to strike the animal at an angle. Let up on the brake pedal just before hitting the animal.

text.default: You are in Car A and there is a large truck opposite you in the intersection that is also turning. Where will it be hardest for you to see any hazards?
text.mandarin: 你在车A中，交叉口对面有一辆大卡车也在转弯。在哪个位置最难看到任何危险？

answer.default: Behind and to the right of the truck
answer.mandarin: 在卡车的后方和右侧

distractor_1.default: Behind you

distractor_2.default: In the lane you are about to enter
distractor_2.mandarin: 在你即将进入的车道中

distractor_3.default: Beside you to the right

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do

text.default: Before you back up, you check your mirrors and do a 360-degree vision check to look for hazards. While backing up,
text.mandarin: 在你倒车之前，你会检查后视镜并进行360度视觉检查以寻找危险。倒车时，

answer.default: Turn and look through the rear window.
answer.mandarin: 转身通过后窗观察。

distractor_1.default: Ensure that both of your hands are firmly placed on the steering wheel
distractor_1.mandarin: 确保双手牢固地放在方向盘上

distractor_2.default: turn on your hazard lights

distractor_3.default: focus on your rear view mirror

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: Be especially careful when you’re backing out of a driveway. It’s easy to miss seeing children, pets, pedestrians, cyclists and people in wheelchairs.

text.default: To maintain proper road (lane) position and to steer your vehicle in smooth line, you should
text.mandarin: 为了保持正确的道路（车道）位置并使车辆行驶在平稳的轨迹上，你应该

answer.default: look well ahead in the direction you want to go.
answer.mandarin: 提前朝着你想要去的方向看。

distractor_1.default: focus on the rear of the vehicle in front of you.
distractor_1.mandarin: 专注于前方车辆的后面。

distractor_2.default: use your mirrors.

distractor_3.default: look at the car beside you and maintain the distance between you.
distractor_3.mandarin: 看着你旁边的车辆，并保持你们之间的距离。

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Steering

text.default: If a line of vehicles has formed behind you and you are driving below the speed limit, why is it a good idea to (safely) pull over to let them pass?
text.mandarin: 如果你后面排成了一列车辆，而你的行驶速度低于限速，为什么安全地靠边停车让它们超车是个好主意？

answer.default: Other drivers behind you may become frustrated and angry and decide to unsafely drive around you
answer.mandarin: 你后面的其他驾驶员可能会变得沮丧和愤怒，并决定不安全地绕过你

distractor_1.default: It is the law

distractor_2.default: Because British Columbians are polite.
distractor_2.mandarin: 因为不列颠哥伦比亚人很有礼貌。

distractor_3.default: You should never be driving below the speed limit
distractor_3.mandarin: 你不应该以低于限速的速度行驶

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Preventing Aggression
question.source: If you use your smart driving skills, allow plenty of space and give others the right-of-way, you can help prevent situations that cause aggression.

text.default: In what driving conditions would you use the two second rule for establishing a safe following distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you?
text.mandarin: 在什么样的驾驶条件下，你会使用两秒规则来确定你的车辆与前方车辆之间的安全跟车距离？

answer.default: Ideal weather conditions and on lower speed roads such as in a city.
answer.mandarin: 理想的天气条件和在低速道路上，比如在城市中。

distractor_1.default: When on a highway.

distractor_2.default: In bad weather conditions.

distractor_3.default: When you are traveling behind a large vehicle.
distractor_3.mandarin: 当你跟在一辆大型车辆后面时。

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins

text.default: You are approaching an intersection with no signs or painted crosswalks. Someone has just stepped off the curb at the intersection to cross the street. You must,
text.mandarin: 你正接近一个没有标志或涂过斑马线的十字路口。有人刚刚从路边踏出要穿过马路。你必须，

answer.default: Yield and be prepared to stop to let them safely cross.
answer.mandarin: 让行并准备停车让他们安全地穿过。

distractor_1.default: Maintain speed through the intersection as pedestrians will yield to vehicles.
distractor_1.mandarin: 通过十字路口时保持速度，因为行人会让车辆。

distractor_2.default: stop and wave the pedestrian across
distractor_2.mandarin: 停车并挥手示意行人穿过

distractor_3.default: always stop at an intersection regardless of whether there are pedestrians
distractor_3.mandarin: 无论是否有行人，都要在十字路口停车

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians

text.default: It is 6pm and there is a school patrol at a crosswalk holding up a stop sign. You can see no children around. What should you do?
text.mandarin: 现在是晚上6点，十字路口有一个学校巡逻员举着停车标志。你看不到周围有孩子。你应该怎么办？

answer.default: Obey the school patrol and stop.
answer.mandarin: 遵守学校巡逻员的指示停车。

distractor_1.default: Slow down and drive slowly through the crosswalk.
distractor_1.mandarin: 放慢速度，慢慢驶过人行横道。

distractor_2.default: it is not during school hours so the school patrol has no business making you stop. Continue through the crosswalk.
distractor_2.mandarin: 现在不是上学时间，所以学校巡逻员没有权力让你停下。继续通过人行横道。

distractor_3.default: Slow down and if you see children, then you should stop.
distractor_3.mandarin: 放慢速度，如果看到孩子，那么你应该停车。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians
question.source: Obey school patrols or crossing supervisors at all times.

text.default: If a pedestrian is crossing the street with a guide dog, a driver should
text.mandarin: 如果有行人带着导盲犬过马路，司机应该

answer.default: Give them extra room as they may be uncertain about where traffic is in relation to them.
answer.mandarin: 给他们更多空间，因为他们可能不确定车辆与他们的位置关系。

distractor_1.default: Not treat them differently than any other pedestrian.
distractor_1.mandarin: 不要和其他行人有任何不同对待。

distractor_2.default: Give a short honk on the horn to let them know it’s alright to cross.
distractor_2.mandarin: 按一下喇叭，让他们知道可以过马路。

distractor_3.default: Drive closer to them as they are listening for the sounds of vehicles.
distractor_3.mandarin: 靠近他们，因为他们在倾听车辆的声音。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians

text.default: Cyclists may swerve to the left and right while on a road as they need to avoid hazards or deal with windy conditions. What is a good practice when passing a cyclist?
text.mandarin: 骑自行车的人在路上可能会左右摇摆，因为他们需要避开障碍物或应对有风的情况。超越骑自行车的人时，什么是一个好的做法？

answer.default: Leave them as much space as possible.
answer.mandarin: 尽量给他们留下更多的空间。

distractor_1.default: honk your horn before passing them.

distractor_2.default: Always maintain your established lane position.
distractor_2.mandarin: 始终保持你的车道位置。

distractor_3.default: only pass cyclists if they are riding in a designated bicycle lane. Otherwise, you are not permitted to pass cyclists.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在他们骑在指定的自行车道时才超越他们。否则，你不允许超越骑自行车的人。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists

text.default: What is this cyclist going to do?
text.mandarin: 这个骑自行车的人将要做什么？

answer.default: turn left
answer.mandarin: 左转

distractor_1.default: stop or slow down

distractor_2.default: turn right

distractor_3.default: get off of their bike

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Communication
question.source: This section has an illustration that shows how cyclists signal left turns, right turns, and stopping or slowing down.

text.default: How much space should you leave beside you while passing a cyclist?
text.mandarin: 在超越骑自行车的人时，你应该在你旁边留下多少空间？

answer.default: Allow as much as is safely possible. One metre or more.
answer.mandarin: 尽可能安全地留下尽可能多的空间。一米或更多。

distractor_1.default: Allow up to a metre between you and the cyclist.
distractor_1.mandarin: 你和骑自行车的人之间应该保持一米左右的距离。

distractor_2.default: You should never pass a cyclist unless they are riding in a designated bicycle lane.
distractor_2.mandarin: 除非他们骑在指定的自行车道上，否则你不应该超越骑自行车的人。

distractor_3.default: Do not adjust your position in the lane.
distractor_3.mandarin: 不要调整你在车道中的位置。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists

text.default: A truck and trailer driving beside you on your right hand side is about to turn right. What hazard should you watch out for most?
text.mandarin: 在你右侧有一辆卡车和挂车即将右转。你应该最注意哪个危险？

answer.default: The truck may swing wide into your lane as it needs space to clear the curb. Slow down and be cautious.
answer.mandarin: 卡车可能会向外摆动进入你的车道，因为它需要空间来绕过路缘石。放慢速度，小心驾驶。

distractor_1.default: There is no reason to be extra cautious. It is the truck driver’s responsibility to make a safe turn.
distractor_1.mandarin: 没有理由特别谨慎。卡车司机有责任进行安全转弯。

distractor_2.default: Pedestrians walking in front of the truck that you can't see.
distractor_2.mandarin: 你看不见的卡车前面可能有行人。

distractor_3.default: The back end of the truck may skid into your lane. You should stop until the truck has turned.
distractor_3.mandarin: 卡车的尾部可能会打滑进入你的车道。你应该停下直到卡车转弯完成。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Large Vehicles

text.default: You are stopped for a school bus that has its red lights flashing. When may you proceed?
text.mandarin: 你停在一辆红灯闪烁的校车前。你什么时候可以继续行驶？

answer.default: You must wait until the lights have stopped flashing. If the bus has a swing-out stop sign, it must also be pulled in.
answer.mandarin: 你必须等到灯停止闪烁。如果校车有一个可伸出的停车标志，它也必须被收回。

distractor_1.default: You must wait for the bus to proceed first.

distractor_2.default: Check for children, then proceed if it appears to be safe.
distractor_2.mandarin: 检查一下有没有孩子，如果看起来安全就继续行驶。

distractor_3.default: When other vehicles start to move.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; School Buses

text.default: When are you required to yield to a public transit bus that has a yield sign on the back and is signaling to enter traffic?
text.mandarin: 在哪些情况下，你需要让给后面有让行标志并示意要进入交通的公交车？

answer.default: on all roads where the speed limit is 60km/h or lower
answer.mandarin: 在所有限速为60公里/小时或更低的道路上

distractor_1.default: always yield to a public transit bus regardless of the posted speed limit.
distractor_1.mandarin: 无论限速标志是多少，始终要让公交车通行。

distractor_2.default: on all roads where the speed limit is 30km/h or lower
distractor_2.mandarin: 在所有限速为30公里/小时或更低的道路上

distractor_3.default: only if there is no traffic behind you
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有当你身后没有车辆时

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Public Transit Buses

text.default: Why is increasing the space margin between you and a car in front of your vehicle a good idea when being tailgated?
text.mandarin: 在被尾随时，增加你和前方车辆之间的安全距离是个好主意，为什么？

answer.default: you can stop more gradually if the car in front suddenly brakes or a hazard appears, reducing the chance of the tailgater crashing into you.
answer.mandarin: 如果前方的车突然刹车或出现危险，你可以更缓慢地停下来，减少尾随者撞上你的可能性。

distractor_1.default: you should actually decrease the space margin to encourage the person in front to speed up.
distractor_1.mandarin: 实际上，你应该减少安全距离，以鼓励前面的人加速。

distractor_2.default: because it will allow the person behind you to more easily pass.
distractor_2.mandarin: 因为这样会让后面的人更容易超车。

distractor_3.default: to let the tailgater know that they have to back away.
distractor_3.mandarin: 让尾随者知道他们必须后退。

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins

text.default: When following a fire truck, how far back must you be?
text.mandarin: 跟随消防车时，你必须保持多远的距离？

answer.default: 150 metres

distractor_1.default: 160 metres

distractor_2.default: 50 metres

distractor_3.default: 60 metres

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Vehicles

text.default: There are many collisions between cars and trains at night because
text.mandarin: 晚上汽车和火车之间发生许多碰撞是因为

answer.default: The side of a train already crossing the road can be difficult to see at night and the car driver does not see the train.
answer.mandarin: 在夜晚，火车横穿道路的一侧可能很难看到，汽车驾驶员看不到火车。

distractor_1.default: headlights were not turned on

distractor_2.default: of driver fatigue

distractor_3.default: of weather conditions

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Trains

text.default: What are the only colours of flashing lights you will find at a railroad crossing?
text.mandarin: 在铁路道口，你只会看到哪种颜色的闪烁灯？

answer.default: Red.
answer.mandarin: 红色。

distractor_1.default: Red and green

distractor_2.default: Red yellow and green

distractor_3.default: Green and yellow

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Trains

text.default: Do you have to stop at intersections with no lights or stop signs (i.e. an uncontrolled intersection)?
text.mandarin: 在没有信号灯或停车标志的十字路口（即无控制的十字路口），你必须停下吗？

answer.default: no, but you should slow down and be prepared to yield to other road users
answer.mandarin: 不必，但你应该减速并准备让其他道路使用者通行。

distractor_1.default: yes, you must always stop at these intersections
distractor_1.mandarin: 是的，你必须始终在这些十字路口停车

distractor_2.default: no. always maintain your speed
distractor_2.mandarin: 不必。始终保持你的速度。

distractor_3.default: no, but use your horn as approach the intersection.
distractor_3.mandarin: 不必，但在接近十字路口时使用你的喇叭。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road Types of Intersections

text.default: You see ahead of you that a traffic light has been green for a long time. What should you do?
text.mandarin: 你看到前方的红绿灯已经亮了很长时间了。你应该怎么做？

answer.default: you should be ready for this stale green light to change. Be prepared to stop if necessary.
answer.mandarin: 你应该准备好这个长时间亮着的绿灯可能会变红。必要时准备停车。

distractor_1.default: look ahead to the intersection and if clear, speed up through the light.
distractor_1.mandarin: 向前看十字路口，如果没有障碍物，加速通过红绿灯。

distractor_2.default: begin braking as this stale green light will soon change.
distractor_2.mandarin: 开始刹车，因为这个长时间亮着的绿灯很快会变红。

distractor_3.default: you do not need to think about the light. It is green.
distractor_3.mandarin: 你不需要考虑灯。它是绿色的。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road Right-of-Way At Intersections

text.default: You are stopped at a railway crossing where there are flashing lights and bells. When are you allowed to proceed?
text.mandarin: 你停在一个铁路道口，那里有闪烁的灯和铃声。你什么时候可以继续前行？

answer.default: you must remain stopped until it is safe to cross
answer.mandarin: 你必须保持停车，直到安全通过为止。

distractor_1.default: when the train has passed and the flashing lights turn yellow
distractor_1.mandarin: 当火车通过并闪烁的灯变成黄色时

distractor_2.default: when you see the green signal

distractor_3.default: when the train has passed

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Trains

text.default: If you are driving slowly and a line of cars forms behind you should,
text.mandarin: 如果你开车慢慢行驶，后面排队的车辆，你应该

answer.default: pull over and stop to let other drivers go by.
answer.mandarin: 靠边停车，让其他司机超车。

distractor_1.default: maintain your speed.

distractor_2.default: slow down and wave to cars to let them know they should pass.
distractor_2.mandarin: 减速并挥手示意其他车辆超车。

distractor_3.default: move to the right and drive on the shoulder.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Preventing Aggression
question.source: Sharing the road means considering other drivers. What messages do your actions give to other drivers?

text.default: In good weather in the city, your minimum following distance should be at LEAST
text.mandarin: 在城市里良好的天气条件下，你的最小跟车距离至少应该是

answer.default: 2 seconds
answer.mandarin: 2秒

distractor_1.default: 4 seconds

distractor_2.default: 1 second

distractor_3.default: 3 seconds

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Always leave a safe following distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. You need at least two seconds of space in front in good weather and road conditions.

text.default: If you are behind a vehicle on an unpaved road, your minimum following distance should be at LEAST
text.mandarin: 如果你在未铺设道路上跟车行驶，你的最小跟车距离至少应该是

answer.default: 3 seconds
answer.mandarin: 3秒

distractor_1.default: 2 seconds

distractor_2.default: 4 seconds

distractor_3.default: 6 seconds

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Allow at least three seconds following distance when you are following another vehicle on an unpaved road where dust or gravel may be in the air.

text.default: What are these cyclists signaling to do?
text.mandarin: 这些骑自行车的人在示意要做什么？

answer.default: Turn right.
answer.mandarin: 向右转。

distractor_1.default: They are about to get off their bikes.

distractor_2.default: Turn left.

distractor_3.default: Stop or slow down.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Communication
question.source: This section has an illustration that shows how cyclists signal left turns, right turns, and stopping or slowing down.

text.default: This sign on a transit bus when it is signalling to enter traffic means
text.mandarin: 当公交车在示意进入交通时，车上的这个标志意味着

answer.default: you must yield to them where the speed limit is 60 km/h or lower.
answer.mandarin: 你必须在限速为60公里/小时或更低的地方让路给它们。

distractor_1.default: yield, regardless of the posted speed limit.
distractor_1.mandarin: 无论限速标志如何，都必须让路给它们。

distractor_2.default: yield on all roads where the speed limit is 30 km/h or lower.
distractor_2.mandarin: 在所有限速为30公里/小时或更低的道路上都必须让路给它们。

distractor_3.default: yield only if there is no traffic behind you.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在你后面没有其他车辆时才需要让路。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Public Transit Buses

text.default: You are in busy traffic and someone is driving too closely behind you. Which of the following actions will help protect you?
text.mandarin: 你在繁忙的交通中，有人在你身后驾驶得太近。以下哪种行为将有助于保护你？

answer.default: Gradually increase the space between you and the vehicle in front of you.
answer.mandarin: 逐渐增加你与前方车辆之间的距离。

distractor_1.default: Decrease the space in front of you to encourage the person in front to speed up.
distractor_1.mandarin: 减少你前面的空间，以促使前方的人加快速度。

distractor_2.default: Accelerate to leave more space behind.
distractor_2.mandarin: 加速以留更多的空间在后方。

distractor_3.default: Honk and flash your brake lights.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: It's a good idea to slow down slightly to increase your space in front. This way, if you have to stop, you can stop more gradually.

text.default: When will you see green lights flashing at a railway crossing?
text.mandarin: 在铁路路口什么时候会看到绿色闪光灯？

answer.default: There are no flashing green lights at a railway crossing.
answer.mandarin: 在铁路路口没有闪烁的绿灯。

distractor_1.default: After the train has passed as a signal for you to go forward.
distractor_1.mandarin: 当火车通过后，作为您前进的信号。

distractor_2.default: When there are no trains coming.

distractor_3.default: At night time to help you see the train signals better.
distractor_3.mandarin: 在夜间，以帮助您更好地看到火车信号。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Trains
question.source: Unlike traffic lights there are no green lights at a railway crossing. When the red railway lights go off and any barriers go up, you may cross the track if the train has passed and it is safe to proceed.

text.default: Do you stop at an uncontrolled intersection?
text.mandarin: 在无控制的十字路口停车吗？

answer.default: You only need to slow down and look out for other road users.
answer.mandarin: 您只需要减速并留意其他道路使用者。

distractor_1.default: You must always stop at uncontrolled intersections.
distractor_1.mandarin: 您必须始终在无控制的十字路口停车。

distractor_2.default: You would maintain speed but watch for other road users.
distractor_2.mandarin: 您会保持速度，但注意其他道路使用者。

distractor_3.default: You would honk to let others know you are there.
distractor_3.mandarin: 您会按喇叭以让其他人知道您在那里。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Types of Intersections
question.source: This is different from when you enter a road from a driveway, alley or parking lot in which case you should always stop before crossing a sidewalk. Make sure you study the rules for the different types of intersections. It’s one of the most common mistakes made when taking our tests.

text.default: Before entering from a side street or alley must the driver of Car A stop before the sidewalk?
text.mandarin: 在从辅路或小巷进入之前，车辆A的驾驶员必须在人行道前停车吗？

answer.default: Yes, you must always stop before crossing a sidewalk out of an alleyway or side street.
answer.mandarin: 是的，您必须始终在通过小巷或辅路时停在人行道前。

distractor_1.default: If the intersection is clear you can just slow down and proceed.
distractor_1.mandarin: 如果十字路口畅通无阻，您只需减速前进。

distractor_2.default: You must stop before the edge of the road.
distractor_2.mandarin: 您必须在路边停车之前停下。

distractor_3.default: You only need to stop if there are pedestrians present.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有当有行人时您才需要停车。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Types of Intersections
question.source: This is different from what you should do at an uncontrolled intersection, which is to slow down and look for other road users. Make sure you study the rules for the different types of intersections.

text.default: When the solid line of a double yellow line is on your side
text.mandarin: 当双黄线的实线在你这一侧时

answer.default: you may not pass.
answer.mandarin: 你不能超车。

distractor_1.default: you may pass only when it’s safe.
distractor_1.mandarin: 只有在安全的情况下才能超车。

distractor_2.default: you may not turn left over the line under any circumstances.
distractor_2.mandarin: 在任何情况下都不能左转越线。

distractor_3.default: you may pass on the right.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: You may not pass however you may make a left turn if you are not impeding other traffic. Yellow lines divide traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken line and a solid line mean you may pass only when it is safe and the broken line is on your side.

text.default: When the solid line of a double yellow line is on your side, are you allowed to make a left turn?
text.mandarin: 当双黄线的实线在你这一侧时，你可以左转吗？

answer.default: Yes as long as you are not impeding other traffic.
answer.mandarin: 是的，只要你不妨碍其他交通。

distractor_1.default: You are not allowed to turn left.

distractor_2.default: Only drivers on the other side of the road may make a left turn.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有在路的另一侧的驾驶员可以左转。

distractor_3.default: Solid yellow lines only indicate rules for passing.
distractor_3.mandarin: 实线黄线仅表示超车规则。

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: It can be confusing when there are two yellow lines in the middle of the street. Just remember if both yellow lines are solid then no passing is allowed in either direction. You may make a left turn as long as you are not impeding other traffic.

text.default: A vehicle skidding is most likely caused by
text.mandarin: 车辆打滑最可能是由于

answer.default: poor driving skills.
answer.mandarin: 驾驶技能不佳。

distractor_1.default: other drivers stopping suddenly.

distractor_2.default: slippery conditions.

distractor_3.default: the mechanical condition of the car.

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Skid Control
question.source: We purposely asked the question this way. Slippery conditions will make a car skid but you can choose to reduce speed or increase your following distance with other vehicles. Think about how you will drive if it is icy on the road. Do you have to drive?

text.default: If driving on a slippery road would you drive at the posted speed limit?
text.mandarin: 如果在湿滑的路上驾驶，你会按照标志的速度限制吗？

answer.default: I can decide to choose a reduced speed that is safe or increase my following distance with other vehicles to avoid skidding.
answer.mandarin: 我可以决定选择一个安全的降速或增加与其他车辆的跟车距离以避免打滑。

distractor_1.default: Yes, as long as I don't go over the speed limit I should be able to avoid skidding.
distractor_1.mandarin: 是的，只要我不超速，我应该能够避免打滑。

distractor_2.default: Only if my vehicle’s tires were designed for all weather conditions.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有当我的车辆轮胎设计用于各种天气条件时才可以。

distractor_3.default: Only if I have snow tires on my vehicle.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有当我车上装有雪地轮胎时才可以。

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies

text.default: Which of the following is NOT something you should do while merging on to a highway?
text.mandarin: 以下哪项不是你在驶入高速公路时应该做的事？

answer.default: Stop and wait for a gap.
answer.mandarin: 停下来等待一个缝隙。

distractor_1.default: Scan for a safe gap.

distractor_2.default: Adjust your speed if necessary using the acceleration lane.
distractor_2.mandarin: 如有必要，使用加速车道调整你的速度。

distractor_3.default: Signal your intention.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Highway or Freeway Entrances and Exits
question.source: Make sure you know how to enter and exit highways and freeways. Don't stop unless you have no other choice.

text.default: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit OUTSIDE of cities and towns is
text.mandarin: 除非另有标示，城镇外的限速是

answer.default: 80 km/h
answer.mandarin: 80 km/h

distractor_1.default: 70 km/h

distractor_2.default: 60 km/h

distractor_3.default: 50 km/h

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think – Do; Appropriate Speeds
question.source: Unless a sign tells you otherwise, the speed limit is 80km/h outside of cities and towns.

text.default: A driver should honk their horn at a cyclist
text.mandarin: 驾驶员应该在遇到骑自行车的情况下按喇叭

answer.default: as a suitable warning.
answer.mandarin: 作为合适的警告。

distractor_1.default: to tell the cyclist to get out of the way.

distractor_2.default: to make the cyclist give you room.
distractor_2.mandarin: 让骑自行车者给你让路。

distractor_3.default: to show that the driver knows that the cyclist is there.
distractor_3.mandarin: 显示驾驶员知道骑自行车者在那里。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Don’t honk your horn at a cyclist unless you need to give a warning. A loud honk could startle a cyclist and even cause a fall.

text.default: You are on a narrow road and want to pass a cyclist, you should
text.mandarin: 你在一条狭窄的道路上，想要超过一个骑自行车的人，你应该

answer.default: wait for a clear, straight stretch that will allow you to pull out and give the cyclist plenty of room as you pass.
answer.mandarin: 等待一个清晰、直的路段，这样你可以开出去并给予骑自行车者足够的空间。

distractor_1.default: pass the cyclist only if they are riding in a designated bicycle lane. Otherwise, you are not permitted to pass cyclists.
distractor_1.mandarin: 只有当他们骑在指定的自行车道上时才可以超过他们。否则，你不被允许超过骑自行车的人。

distractor_2.default: honk your horn to let them know you want to pass.
distractor_2.mandarin: 按喇叭告诉他们你想超车。

distractor_3.default: pass them as it is a cyclist’s responsibility to yield to vehicles.
distractor_3.mandarin: 超过他们，因为骑自行车的人有责任让车辆让路。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Cyclists are vulnerable to being hit while being passed. Wait for a clear, straight stretch that will allow you to pull out and give the cyclist plenty of room as you pass

text.default: In heavy traffic, how can you help a cyclist who may want to change lanes and turn left at an intersection?
text.mandarin: 在拥堵的交通中，你如何帮助一个可能想要变换车道并在十字路口左转的骑自行车者？

answer.default: Leave extra room so the cyclist can safely change lanes.
answer.mandarin: 留出额外的空间，让骑自行车者可以安全地变换车道。

distractor_1.default: Honk at the cyclist and wave them across.
distractor_1.mandarin: 按喇叭并挥手示意骑自行车者通过。

distractor_2.default: Maintain your lane position.

distractor_3.default: Move into another lane so that other drivers can see their hand signals.
distractor_3.mandarin: 进入另一个车道，以便其他驾驶员能看到他们的手势信号。

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Honking your horn could startle them and using gestures can sometimes be misunderstood.

text.default: A steady yellow light means:
text.mandarin: 稳定的黄灯意味着：

answer.default: stop unless it is unsafe to do so.
answer.mandarin: 停车，除非这样做是不安全的。

distractor_1.default: stop only if there are other vehicles in the intersection.
distractor_1.mandarin: 只有在十字路口有其他车辆时停车。

distractor_2.default: stop in all cases.

distractor_3.default: accelerate if you know you can make it through before it turns red.
distractor_3.mandarin: 如果你知道你能在它变红之前通过，那就加速。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: Yellow means that the signal is about the turn red. You must stop before entering the intersection unless you cannot safely stop in time.

text.default: Vehicles at a four-way stop intersection must yield to the vehicle on their right UNLESS:
text.mandarin: 在四路停车交叉口，车辆必须让右侧的车辆先行，除非：

answer.default: another vehicle comes to a complete stop before them.
answer.mandarin: 另一辆车在他们之前完全停下来。

distractor_1.default: another vehicle who got there first waves you on.
distractor_1.mandarin: 另一辆车比你先到，然后示意你先走。

distractor_2.default: another vehicle is a bus.
distractor_2.mandarin: 另一辆车是一辆公共汽车。

distractor_3.default: pedestrians are walking in front of the other vehicles. So you can go first.
distractor_3.mandarin: 行人在其他车辆前面行走，所以你可以先行。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: If someone does take the right of way from you by going first, yield to the other driver for safety.

text.default: If two vehicles arrive at a 4-way stop intersection at the same time and are facing each other
text.mandarin: 如果两辆车同时到达四路停车交叉口并且彼此面对面

answer.default: a vehicle that is going straight through may go first.
answer.mandarin: 直行的车辆可以先行。

distractor_1.default: a vehicle that is turning may go first.

distractor_2.default: it is always ok if both vehicles move at the same time.
distractor_2.mandarin: 如果两辆车同时移动，总是可以的。

distractor_3.default: always wait for the other vehicle to move first.
distractor_3.mandarin: 总是等待另一辆车先行。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: If someone does take the right of way from you by going first, yield to the other driver for safety.

text.default: You have passed the acceleration area and are ready to merge. You should first:
text.mandarin: 你已经通过了加速区，准备合并。你应该首先：

answer.default: look to your left and behind for a safe gap.
answer.mandarin: 向左侧和后方寻找安全的间隙。

distractor_1.default: slow down.

distractor_2.default: keep speeding up.

distractor_3.default: use a hand signal to merge into traffic.
distractor_3.mandarin: 使用手势信号合并到交通中。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Highway or Freeway Entrances and Exits

text.default: Why is it important to come to a complete stop for a yellow light when possible?
text.mandarin: 为什么在可能的情况下停车等待黄灯是很重要的？

answer.default: All of these.
answer.mandarin: 所有这些。

distractor_1.default: It is the law.

distractor_2.default: It is the safest thing to do.

distractor_3.default: To avoid a collision.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: Think about opposing traffic turning left. If you go through the yellow light and they turn can you avoid a crash? It’s only a short wait at the light.

text.default: One way in which a passenger can help the driver to drive safely is by
text.mandarin: 乘客可以通过以下哪种方式帮助司机安全驾驶？

answer.default: avoiding conversations that could distract the driver.
answer.mandarin: 避免可能会分散司机注意力的谈话。

distractor_1.default: talking loudly so that the driver can hear the conversation.
distractor_1.mandarin: 大声交谈，以便司机能听到对话。

distractor_2.default: turning up the radio.

distractor_3.default: asking questions to keep the driver alert.
distractor_3.mandarin: 询问问题以保持司机警觉。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Unsafe Passengers
question.source: When you are driving, your mind and senses should be focused only on driving. Distractions can affect your hazard perception and your reaction time.

text.default: When other drivers act aggressively towards you, it’s best to
text.mandarin: 当其他驾驶员对你采取攻击性行为时，最好的做法是

answer.default: avoid eye contact and give the other driver plenty of room.
answer.mandarin: 避免眼神接触，并给其他驾驶员足够的空间。

distractor_1.default: return the aggression, or they’ll think they can do what they want.
distractor_1.mandarin: 回敬攻击，否则他们会认为他们可以为所欲为。

distractor_2.default: drive more slowly, but take your right of way.
distractor_2.mandarin: 开得更慢，但保留你的通行权。

distractor_3.default: try to pass them and leave them behind.
distractor_3.mandarin: 试图超过他们，将他们甩在身后。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Aggression on the road
question.source: If you use your smart driving skills, allow plenty of space and give others the right-of-way, you can help prevent situations that cause aggression.

text.default: The vehicle on the right is at more risk of losing traction around a curve because
text.mandarin: 在转弯时，右侧的车辆更容易失去牵引力，因为

answer.default: it has a higher centre of gravity than the vehicle on the left.
answer.mandarin: 它的重心比左侧的车辆更高。

distractor_1.default: it has larger tires than the vehicle on the left.
distractor_1.mandarin: 它的轮胎比左侧的车辆更大。

distractor_2.default: it's actually at less risk because it has bigger brakes.
distractor_2.mandarin: 实际上，它的风险较小，因为它的制动器更大。

distractor_3.default: it's actually at less risk because the driver can see better.
distractor_3.mandarin: 实际上，它的风险较小，因为驾驶员可以看得更清楚。

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: A vehicle with a higher centre of gravity is less stable on uneven road surfaces and is more likely to tip over on a curve taken at higher speeds.

text.default: You’re driving around a curve and you start to lose traction. What should you do?
text.mandarin: 当你在转弯时开始失去牵引力时，你应该怎么做？

answer.default: Ease off the accelerator and re-apply gently when you regain traction.
answer.mandarin: 松开油门，当你重新获得牵引力时轻轻重新加速。

distractor_1.default: Pump the brakes.

distractor_2.default: Speed up.

distractor_3.default: Apply the brakes firmly.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Handling Curves

text.default: You’re driving with your high beam headlights on and a car is approaching. You must dim them when the approaching car is within
text.mandarin: 当你开启远光灯行驶时，一辆车正在接近。当接近的车辆在

answer.default: 150 metres.
answer.mandarin: 150米内时，你必须将灯光调暗。

distractor_1.default: 200 metres.

distractor_2.default: 50 metres.

distractor_3.default: 100 metres.

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Using the Headlights
question.source: Do you have trouble judging distances? Most people do. Be courteous and dim your headlights as early as you can.

text.default: Headlights must be used
text.mandarin: 车头灯必须使用

answer.default: from 30 minutes after sunset until 30 minutes before sunrise.
answer.mandarin: 从日落后30分钟到日出前30分钟。

distractor_1.default: overnight.

distractor_2.default: during the day.

distractor_3.default: from dawn to dusk.

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; Using the Headlights
question.source: It's a safe practice to turn on your headlights whenever it seems dark such as in heavy rain or driving in dark valleys.

text.default: Which of the following should you NOT do after being involved in a crash?
text.mandarin: 在事故发生后，以下哪项是你不应该做的？

answer.default: Discuss who is at fault for the crash.
answer.mandarin: 讨论事故责任归属。

distractor_1.default: Move the vehicles off the road if it is safe to do so.
distractor_1.mandarin: 如果安全的话，将车辆移到路边。

distractor_2.default: Exchange driver’s licence numbers with any other drivers involved.
distractor_2.mandarin: 与任何其他涉及的驾驶员交换驾驶证号码。

distractor_3.default: Draw a sketch or take photos of the scene, noting conditions such as time, location and weather.
distractor_3.mandarin: 绘制草图或拍摄现场照片，记录时间、地点和天气等情况。

question.chapter: Chapter 8: Emergency Strategies; At the Scene of a Crash
question.source: It will be up to your insurer to assess damages and law enforcement to assess any fines.

text.default: The MINIMUM safe following distance of two seconds behind the car ahead of you is
text.mandarin: 你跟车的最小安全距离是

answer.default: for ideal conditions in the city.
answer.mandarin: 城市中的理想条件。

distractor_1.default: always the rule.

distractor_2.default: for only bad weather conditions.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有在恶劣的天气条件下。

distractor_3.default: only on highways.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins

text.default: At intersections with no lights or stop signs, you should
text.mandarin: 在没有红绿灯或停车标志的十字路口，你应该

answer.default: slow down, cover the brake pedal and look both ways as you near the intersection.
answer.mandarin: 减速，踩住制动踏板，并在接近十字路口时两侧观察。

distractor_1.default: slow down and stop at the intersection.

distractor_2.default: maintain your speed and scan the intersection.
distractor_2.mandarin: 保持速度并扫描十字路口。

distractor_3.default: slow down as you enter the intersection.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Types of Intersections
question.source: This is different from when you enter a road from a driveway, alley or parking lot in which case you should always stop before crossing a sidewalk. Make sure you study the rules for the different types of intersections. It’s one of the most common mistakes made when taking our tests.

text.default: What signal at an intersection would be treated the same as a stop sign?
text.mandarin: 在十字路口，哪种信号会被视为停车标志？

answer.default: A flashing red light.
answer.mandarin: 闪烁的红灯。

distractor_1.default: A flashing yellow light.

distractor_2.default: A flashing green light.

distractor_3.default: A steady yellow light.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: If there is a power outage and no lights at all, you would also treat the intersection the same as a stop sign.

text.default: Are you allowed to use hands-free 'voice to text' features on your phone while operating a vehicle if you have your learner's (L) or novice (N) licence?
text.mandarin: 在驾驶车辆时，如果你持有学习（L）或新手（N）驾照，你可以使用免提的“语音转文本”功能吗？

answer.default: You are not allowed to operate hands-free electronic devices at any time while driving.
answer.mandarin: 你不允许在驾驶过程中任何时候使用免提电子设备。

distractor_1.default: Only during daylight hours.

distractor_2.default: Only if the device requires one touch to activate or deactivate.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有当设备需要一个触摸来激活或停用时才能使用。

distractor_3.default: Only when a qualified supervisor is driving with you.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在有合格监督员陪同驾驶时才能使用。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused
question.source: This includes pre-programmed or voice-activated GPS devices.

text.default: While operating a vehicle, if you have your learner’s (L) or novice licence (N) are you allowed to use hands free ‘voice to text’ on your phone while driving?
text.mandarin: 在驾驶车辆时，如果你持有学习（L）或新手（N）驾照，你可以使用免提的“语音转文本”功能吗？

answer.default: You are not allowed to operate hands-free electronic devices at any time while driving.
answer.mandarin: 你不允许在驾驶过程中任何时候使用免提电子设备。

distractor_1.default: Only during daylight hours.

distractor_2.default: Only if the device requires one touch to activate or deactivate the voice command.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有当设备需要一个触摸来激活或停用语音命令时才能使用。

distractor_3.default: Only when a qualified supervisor is driving with you.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在有合格监督员陪同驾驶时才能使用。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused
question.source: This includes pre-programmed or voice-activated GPS devices.

text.default: When approaching stopped emergency vehicles displaying flashing lights you must
text.mandarin: 当接近展示闪烁灯的停止的紧急车辆时，你必须

answer.default: slow down and change lanes if traffic permits.
answer.mandarin: 减速并在交通情况允许的情况下换道。

distractor_1.default: be ready to get out of the way.

distractor_2.default: move to either side of the road and stop.
distractor_2.mandarin: 移到路边的任一侧并停下。

distractor_3.default: stop immediately.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Workers on Roads

text.default: When approaching a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights on highways with speed limits of 80 km/h or over, in addition to changing lanes, you must slow to
text.mandarin: 在速度限制为80公里/小时或以上的高速公路上接近一辆停在路边的紧急车辆，除了换道外，你必须减速至

answer.default: 70 km/h.
answer.mandarin: 70公里/小时。

distractor_1.default: 40 km/h.

distractor_2.default: 50 km/h.

distractor_3.default: 30 km/h.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Workers on Roads

text.default: When approaching a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights on highways with speed limits of under 80 km/h, in addition to changing lanes, you must slow to
text.mandarin: 在速度限制低于80公里/小时的高速公路上接近一辆停在路边的紧急车辆，除了换道外，你必须减速至

answer.default: 40 km/h.
answer.mandarin: 40公里/小时。

distractor_1.default: 70 km/h.

distractor_2.default: 60 km/h.

distractor_3.default: 50 km/h.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Workers on Roads

distractor_1.default: Car C

distractor_2.default: Car A

distractor_3.default: Car D

distractor_3.mandarin: 此路口允许左转和右转。

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.mandarin: 这个标志的意思是：

distractor_1.default: No lane changes allowed.

distractor_2.default: One-way traffic only.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.mandarin: 这个标志意味着减速至30公里/小时：

answer.default: Every day from dawn to dusk.
answer.mandarin: 每天从黎明到黄昏。

distractor_1.default: When you see children on road.
distractor_1.mandarin: 当你看到路上有孩子时。

distractor_2.default: Weekdays from dawn to dusk.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.default: This sign means:
text.mandarin: 这个标志的意思是：

answer.default: Playground nearby - drive with caution.
answer.mandarin: 附近有游乐场 - 行驶时要小心。

distractor_1.default: Slow to 30 km/h if pedestrians crossing.
distractor_1.mandarin: 如果有行人横穿，减速至30公里/小时。

distractor_2.default: Sports stadium nearby - watch for hazards.
distractor_2.mandarin: 附近有体育场 - 注意危险。

distractor_3.default: School crosswalk - stop for pedestrians.
distractor_3.mandarin: 学校人行横道 - 为行人停车。

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.default: A steady green arrow means:
text.mandarin: 稳定的绿色箭头表示：

answer.default: You may turn in the direction of the arrow if the intersection is clear.
answer.mandarin: 如果路口畅通，你可以朝箭头指示的方向转弯。

distractor_1.default: The cross-street is a one way street in the direction of the arrow.
distractor_1.mandarin: 横过的街道是单行道，方向与箭头相同。

distractor_2.default: You may turn in the direction of the arrow after coming to a complete stop.
distractor_2.mandarin: 在完全停车后，你可以朝箭头指示的方向转弯。

distractor_3.default: You may only turn left at this intersection.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.default: A steady red light means:
text.mandarin: 稳定的红灯表示：

answer.default: Stop. After coming to a full stop you may turn right or turn left onto a one-way street unless a sign forbids it.
answer.mandarin: 停车。完全停下后，你可以右转或者左转进入单行道，除非有禁止标志。

distractor_1.default: Stop if traffic is approaching.

distractor_2.default: You must stop unless you are turning right.
distractor_2.mandarin: 除非你要右转，否则你必须停车。

distractor_3.default: Stop, then proceed when safe.
distractor_3.mandarin: 停车，然后在安全时继续行驶。

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.default: A flashing red light means:
text.mandarin: 闪烁的红灯表示：

answer.default: Stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.
answer.mandarin: 停车，等待安全时继续行驶。

distractor_1.default: Stop until the light changes to a flashing green light.
distractor_1.mandarin: 停车，直到红灯变成闪烁的绿灯。

distractor_2.default: Slow down and proceed through intersection if safe.
distractor_2.mandarin: 减速通过路口，如果安全的话。

distractor_3.default: Stop until the light changes to a flashing yellow light.
distractor_3.mandarin: 停车，直到红灯变成闪烁的黄灯。

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.mandarin: 闪烁的黄色交通灯意味着：

answer.mandarin: 减速并准备停车。

distractor_1.default: The light is about to change to red.

distractor_2.default: Stop.

distractor_3.default: The light is about to change to green.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings

text.default: If you are in the Graduated Licensing Program (GLP), are you allowed to use a GPS navigation device while driving?
text.mandarin: 如果你在分级驾驶许可计划（GLP）中，驾驶时可以使用GPS导航设备吗？

answer.default: No, using a GPS as an electronic device can be a distraction.
answer.mandarin: 不可以，使用GPS作为电子设备可能会分散注意力。

distractor_1.default: Only if the destination is programmed into the GPS before driving.
distractor_1.mandarin: 只有在驾驶前将目的地输入GPS才可以。

distractor_2.default: Only if the GPS device is guiding you by audio (i.e. on speaker).
distractor_2.mandarin: 只有当GPS设备通过音频引导你时才可以（例如，通过扬声器）。

distractor_3.default: Only when stopped such as at a red traffic light.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在停车时才可以，比如在红灯时。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal strategies
question.source: GLP drivers are restricted from operating hands-free electronic devices while driving.

text.default: While driving, a hand held device may be used to…
text.mandarin: 驾驶时，手持设备可用于……

answer.default: none of these are allowed.
answer.mandarin: 以上都不允许。

distractor_1.default: view an email or text.

distractor_2.default: select songs on your vehicle's audio system.
distractor_2.mandarin: 在车辆音频系统上选择歌曲。

distractor_3.default: check for directions via GPS.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal strategies
question.source: You can use your phone to dial 911 in an emergency only. Using your cell phone without a hands-free device while driving in any other situation is illegal and will result in penalties and fines.

text.default: I am allowed to check text messages in my vehicle…
text.mandarin: 我可以在车辆中查看短信……

answer.default: when the vehicle is safely parked off the roadway.
answer.mandarin: 当车辆安全停在路边时。

distractor_1.default: when stopped at a red traffic light.

distractor_2.default: when stopped in heavy traffic.
distractor_2.mandarin: 在拥堵的交通中停车时。

distractor_3.default: all of these are allowed.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal strategies
question.source: If you do need to make or receive a call, pull over as soon as it's safe to do so; stay focused on the road and keep the conversation brief.

text.default: As a Class 7 L or N driver, I am allowed to use my hands free device while driving…
text.mandarin: 作为七级（L）或新手（N）驾驶员，我可以在驾驶时使用我的免提设备……

answer.default: for emergency calls only.
answer.mandarin: 仅用于紧急电话。

distractor_1.default: for skipping through music tracks when connected to my vehicle's audio system.
distractor_1.mandarin: 当连接到车辆音频系统时跳过音乐曲目。

distractor_2.default: to check the map on GPS.

distractor_3.default: never.

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal strategies
question.source: You can use your phone to dial 911 in an emergency only. Using your cell phone without a hands-free device while driving in any other situation is illegal and will result in penalties and fines.

text.default: You're driving at the speed limit in the left lane of an 80km/h multi-lane highway. A car approaches from behind. You must:
text.mandarin: 你正在一条限速80公里/小时的多车道高速公路的左侧车道以限速行驶。一辆车从后面接近。你必须：

answer.default: safely pull into to nearest lane on your right to let the other vehicle pass.
answer.mandarin: 安全地驶入最靠右的车道，让后方车辆超车。

distractor_1.default: maintain your lane position.

distractor_2.default: increase your speed to match the vehicle behind you.
distractor_2.mandarin: 加速以匹配你后面的车辆速度。

distractor_3.default: slow down to give yourself more space to safely brake.
distractor_3.mandarin: 减速以给自己更多安全刹车的空间。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the road
question.source: When on a multi-lane highway with a posted speed limit above 80km/h and traffic moving at least 50km/h, you must avoid using the left lane if it blocks other drivers from passing. Drivers who block the left lane increase the risk caused by aggressive drivers who may try to pass on the right or tailgate.

text.default: You're driving 90km/h in the left lane of a multi-lane highway in a rural area. Must you move over to the right?
text.mandarin: 你在农村地区的多车道高速公路的左车道以90公里/小时的速度行驶。你必须换到右边车道吗？

answer.default: Unless any vehicle approaches from behind, you may stay in the left lane to keep a greater distance from any wildlife on the road.
answer.mandarin: 除非有车辆从后面接近，你可以留在左车道，以便与道路上的野生动物保持更大的距离。

distractor_1.default: You're always required to keep right on high speed roads unless passing.
distractor_1.mandarin: 在高速公路上，除了超车外，你总是要靠右行驶。

distractor_2.default: You may stay in the left lane as long as you're driving at the speed limit.
distractor_2.mandarin: 只要你以限速行驶，你可以留在左车道。

distractor_3.default: Only if emergency vehicles with flashing lights are approaching you from behind.
distractor_3.mandarin: 只有在有闪光灯的急救车从后面靠近时。

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the road
question.source: If there's no traffic behind you it is permitted to drive in the left lane. On rural roads it is sometimes safer to stay in the left to avoid wildlife near the highway. When a vehicle approaches from behind move over to the right to let them pass.

text.default: Can I listen to music from my electronic device while driving?
text.mandarin: 我可以在驾驶时听我电子设备中的音乐吗？

answer.default: Yes, you can listen to music from an electronic device while driving, provided that it is connected to the in-vehicle audio system, and you don't touch any electronic devices while operating the vehicle.
answer.mandarin: 是的，您可以在驾驶时从电子设备中听音乐，只要它连接到车辆的音响系统，并且您在操作车辆时不触摸任何电子设备。

distractor_1.default: Yes, you can listen to music from an electronic device while driving, provided that you are wearing earbuds or an ear piece
distractor_1.mandarin: 是的，您可以在驾驶时从电子设备中听音乐，只要您戴着耳塞或耳机。

distractor_2.default: No, you may not connect your electronic device in advance and listen to music with your in-vehicle system.
distractor_2.mandarin: 不，您不可以提前连接您的电子设备并使用车辆的系统来听音乐。

distractor_3.default: Yes, you can listen to music from an electronic device while driving, as long as the device is securely attached to the vehicle's dashboard.
distractor_3.mandarin: 是的，您可以在驾驶时从电子设备中听音乐，只要设备安全地固定在车辆的仪表板上。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused

text.default: Which of the following would not qualify as an emergency call that I can make while driving?
text.mandarin: 以下哪种情况不符合我在驾驶时可以拨打的紧急电话？

answer.default: To a family member
answer.mandarin: 给家人

distractor_1.default: To the police

distractor_2.default: To the fire department

distractor_3.default: To ambulance services

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused

text.default: When can I use a personal electronic device if I'm in the Graduated Licensing Program (GLP)?
text.mandarin: 如果我在毕业驾驶许可计划（GLP）中，我什么时候可以使用个人电子设备？

answer.default: None of the above - I cannot use a personal electronic device in the GLP
answer.mandarin: 以上都不对 - 在GLP中我不能使用个人电子设备

distractor_1.default: I've been in the program for at least six months
distractor_1.mandarin: 我至少已经参加了六个月的计划

distractor_2.default: I've secured my cell phone to the vehicle
distractor_2.mandarin: 我已经把我的手机固定在车上

distractor_3.default: I'm using a speaker phone or hands-free phone
distractor_3.mandarin: 我正在使用免提电话或蓝牙电话

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused

text.default: If I am at a red light or stopped in traffic, can I look at a text I just received?
text.mandarin: 如果我在红灯或交通停滞中，我可以查看刚收到的短信吗？

answer.default: No, you may not operate your cell phone while on the road including when you're stopped in traffic.
answer.mandarin: 不可以，在路上包括在交通停滞中时，您不得使用手机。

distractor_1.default: Yes, you can quickly look at your screen but not reply to any messages.
distractor_1.mandarin: 可以，您可以快速看一下屏幕，但不能回复任何消息。

distractor_2.default: Yes, whenever a vehicle is not moving means you're not driving.
distractor_2.mandarin: 可以，只要车辆不移动意味着您不在驾驶。

distractor_3.default: Yes, as long as the light has just turned red. You have about a minute to safely use your phone.
distractor_3.mandarin: 可以，只要红灯刚刚亮起。您有大约一分钟的时间安全地使用手机。

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Keeping Focused
